speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Titus's garden.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter young LUCIUS, and LAVINIA running after him,  and the boy flies from her, with books under his arm. Then enter TITUS and MARCUS

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Help, grandsire, help! my aunt Lavinia

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Follows me every where, I know not why:

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Good uncle Marcus, see how swift she comes.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Alas, sweet aunt, I know not what you mean.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Stand by me, Lucius; do not fear thine aunt.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: She loves thee, boy, too well to do thee harm.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Ay, when my father was in Rome she did.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What means my niece Lavinia by these signs?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Fear her not, Lucius: somewhat doth she mean:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Somewhither would she have thee go with her.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ah, boy, Cornelia never with more care

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Read to her sons than she hath read to thee

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sweet poetry and Tully's Orator.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess,

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her:

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: For I have heard my grandsire say full oft,

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Extremity of griefs would make men mad;

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: And I have read that Hecuba of Troy

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Ran mad through sorrow: that made me to fear;

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Although, my lord, I know my noble aunt

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Loves me as dear as e'er my mother did,

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: And would not, but in fury, fright my youth:

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Which made me down to throw my books, and fly--

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Causeless, perhaps. But pardon me, sweet aunt:

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: And, madam, if my uncle Marcus go,

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: I will most willingly attend your ladyship.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lucius, I will.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: LAVINIA turns over with her stumps the books which LUCIUS has let fall

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How now, Lavinia! Marcus, what means this?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Some book there is that she desires to see.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Which is it, girl, of these? Open them, boy.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But thou art deeper read, and better skill'd

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, and take choice of all my library,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I think she means that there was more than one

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Confederate in the fact: ay, more there was;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lucius, what book is that she tosseth so?

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Grandsire, 'tis Ovid's Metamorphoses;

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: My mother gave it me.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For love of her that's gone,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Perhaps she cull'd it from among the rest.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Soft! see how busily she turns the leaves!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Helping her

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What would she find? Lavinia, shall I read?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This is the tragic tale of Philomel,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And treats of Tereus' treason and his rape:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And rape, I fear, was root of thine annoy.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: See, brother, see; note how she quotes the leaves.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lavinia, wert thou thus surprised, sweet girl,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ravish'd and wrong'd, as Philomela was,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Forced in the ruthless, vast, and gloomy woods? See, see!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ay, such a place there is, where we did hunt--

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, had we never, never hunted there!--

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Pattern'd by that the poet here describes,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: By nature made for murders and for rapes.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, why should nature build so foul a den,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Unless the gods delight in tragedies?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Give signs, sweet girl, for here are none

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: but friends,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What Roman lord it was durst do the deed:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That left the camp to sin in Lucrece' bed?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sit down, sweet niece: brother, sit down by me.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Apollo, Pallas, Jove, or Mercury,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Inspire me, that I may this treason find!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord, look here: look here, Lavinia:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This sandy plot is plain; guide, if thou canst

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This after me, when I have writ my name

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Without the help of any hand at all.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He writes his name with his staff, and guides it with feet and mouth

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Cursed be that heart that forced us to this shift!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Write thou good niece; and here display, at last,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What God will have discover'd for revenge;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That we may know the traitors and the truth!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: She takes the staff in her mouth, and guides it with her stumps, and writes

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, do ye read, my lord, what she hath writ?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Stuprum. Chiron. Demetrius.'

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What, what! the lustful sons of Tamora

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Performers of this heinous, bloody deed?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Magni Dominator poli,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tam lentus audis scelera? tam lentus vides?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, calm thee, gentle lord; although I know

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: There is enough written upon this earth

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord, kneel down with me; Lavinia, kneel;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And kneel, sweet boy, the Roman Hector's hope;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And swear with me, as, with the woful fere

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And father of that chaste dishonour'd dame,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lord Junius Brutus sware for Lucrece' rape,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That we will prosecute by good advice

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Goths,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And see their blood, or die with this reproach.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis sure enough, an you knew how.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But if you hunt these bear-whelps, then beware:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The dam will wake; and, if she wind you once,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: She's with the lion deeply still in league,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And lulls him whilst she playeth on her back,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And when he sleeps will she do what she list.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You are a young huntsman, Marcus; let it alone;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, come, I will go get a leaf of brass,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And with a gad of steel will write these words,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And lay it by: the angry northern wind

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will blow these sands, like Sibyl's leaves, abroad,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And where's your lesson, then? Boy, what say you?

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: I say, my lord, that if I were a man,

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Their mother's bed-chamber should not be safe

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: For these bad bondmen to the yoke of Rome.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ay, that's my boy! thy father hath full oft

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For his ungrateful country done the like.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: And, uncle, so will I, an if I live.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, go with me into mine armoury;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lucius, I'll fit thee; and withal, my boy,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Shalt carry from me to the empress' sons

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Presents that I intend to send them both:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, come; thou'lt do thy message, wilt thou not?

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Ay, with my dagger in their bosoms, grandsire.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No, boy, not so; I'll teach thee another course.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lavinia, come. Marcus, look to my house:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lucius and I'll go brave it at the court:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ay, marry, will we, sir; and we'll be waited on.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt TITUS, LAVINIA, and Young LUCIUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O heavens, can you hear a good man groan,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And not relent, or not compassion him?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Marcus, attend him in his ecstasy,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That hath more scars of sorrow in his heart

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Than foemen's marks upon his batter'd shield;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But yet so just that he will not revenge.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Revenge, ye heavens, for old Andronicus!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exit
